name: European Central Bank
tweet: Do liquidity policy measures hurt fund investors? Our latest Macroprudential Bulletin shows that pre-emptive liquidity measures make funds more resilient and investors safer, especially when market liquidity is low. Read more  https://t.co/XVgv41BJLr  https://t.co/mUfteF5QNA

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Panetta: Responses to the public consultation show the high expectations that people have for a digital euro. They will provide valuable input for our work and decision on whether to start a digital euro project. We will move rapidly but take the time to do it right 3/3

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Panetta: Protecting privacy will be a priority so that the digital euro helps maintain trust in digital payments. Our preliminary experimentation shows how technology can be used to protect privacy without relaxing standards against illicit activities  https://t.co/1KUR7ba3Bq 2/3

name: European Central Bank
tweet: (THREAD) The record participation in our public consultation and willingness of citizens and professionals to support a digital euro are encouraging. The most valued features are privacy, security and broad usability. Speech  https://t.co/YO6QNjT8sN 1/3  https://t.co/dOT1WgQjCj

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Coming up at 13:45 CET: Executive Board member Fabio Panetta will present the outcome of the public consultation on a digital euro at the European Parliament’s Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs @EP_Economics. Follow live  https://t.co/SkamHnaGuA

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Fiscal, monetary and supervisory authorities have reduced the economic and social costs of the crisis. They face a delicate balancing act between the risk of withdrawing measures too early and keeping them in place for too long.

name: European Central Bank
tweet: We saw the largest economic contraction recorded in post-war history in 2020. Uncertainty remains high, but thanks to vaccinations, the easing of confinement measures and fiscal and monetary support the economy should pick up strongly in the second half of 2021.

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Last year has been exceptionally challenging for all of us, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos as he presents our Annual Report to the European Parliament’s Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee @EP_Economics   https://t.co/8uZz4RJWlT  https://t.co/6qzBg7GWwd  https://t.co/IPoaY60ec8

name: European Central Bank
tweet: We received more than 8,000 replies to our public consultation on a digital euro, mostly from citizens and the rest from businesses and professionals in the payments sector.  Have a look at their views  https://t.co/enbOpUWFfl

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Privacy is the most important feature of a #digitaleuro for both citizens and professionals, with security and the ability to pay across the euro area close behind. Respondents want innovative services integrated into existing payment systems.  https://t.co/4isT5AcL9c

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Many European investment funds stopped investors withdrawing capital during the market turmoil at the onset of the pandemic. name: European Central Bank
tweet: Panetta: In the coming months we will decide whether to start investigating a digital euro – a form of money backed up by the ECB that allows Europeans to make secure digital payments. We could be ready to launch a digital euro within five years 3/3

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Panetta: The pandemic has affected each country differently, but there has been a strong common European response. The EU recovery plan could serve as a prototype for a future common fiscal instrument 2/3

name: European Central Bank
tweet: EU rules require banks to maintain enough capital to cover unexpected losses. A bank can use a standardised approach or its own internal models to calculate this capital requirement. We explain how this works and how we supervise banks’ internal models  https://t.co/Xi5kP4GDEG  https://t.co/IyriTxxt8v

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Lane: Offsetting the negative shock to inflation is only the first stage of the monetary policy challenge. Even after disinflationary pressures have been sufficiently offset, we will have to ensure timely and robust convergence to our inflation aim over the medium term. 3/3

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Lane: The increase in inflation during 2021 can be best interpreted as the unwinding of disinflationary forces that took hold in 2020. It does not constitute the basis for a sustained shift in inflation dynamics 2/3

name: European Central Bank
tweet: (THREAD) The recent volatility of inflation can be largely attributed to the nature of the pandemic shock, writes Chief Economist Philip R. Lane on #TheECBBlog.  Read his blog post  https://t.co/G1mVYI15WU 1/3  https://t.co/6LppEEycdN

name: European Central Bank
tweet: How has the euro short-term rate €STR performed since its introduction?  Discover this and more in our insights released on the euro area statistics website, available in 23 EU languages  https://t.co/xfBOD3MTXV  https://t.co/5ZmeCGAVz8

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Targeted longer-term refinancing operations encourage banks to keep credit flowing to people and businesses and keep their borrowing costs low. This, in turn, supports spending and investment in the economy. Check out our explainer to find out more  https://t.co/xUD5k1kuvV  https://t.co/KGpeVQDruP

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Tonight, we join the rest of the #Frankfurt skyline for #EarthHour 2021 to raise awareness of the fight against climate change.   ➡️ Check out what else we do to tackle climate change  https://t.co/I7pk4eDaJU ➡️ Find out more about Earth Hour  https://t.co/buyjHc9Ph8  https://t.co/LgCixd2ZD9

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Lane: Complementing our accommodative monetary policy, fiscal policy needs to counter the pandemic shock to incomes and the productive capacity of firms. It needs to ensure that overall demand conditions promote a timely recovery and underpin medium-term growth prospects 3/3

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Lane: Shorter-term and longer-term economic performance are inextricably linked, especially in the current circumstances. A sustained period of below-capacity economic activity damages the longer-term level of potential output 2/3

name: European Central Bank
tweet: (Thread) Our commitment to preserving favourable financing conditions acts as a stabilising force and boosts confidence, says Chief Economist Philip R. Lane. It counters the risks of self-fulfilling adverse dynamics that may affect the economic outlook  https://t.co/QqPp1XKGBl 1/3  https://t.co/Bn6bsmJgrP

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Our decision to step up monthly emergency purchases is based on a thorough assessment of the drivers of recent yield increases, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. There was a risk of an abrupt and premature withdrawal of vital policy support  https://t.co/jajKcJiVBl  https://t.co/Gd4PSDwJUy

name: European Central Bank
tweet: More attention should be paid to the stability risks if the ECB does not offer a digital currency. Preparing for a digital euro protects Europe’s autonomy. We must ensure our single currency is future-proof and fit for the digital age. Read more  https://t.co/UMqavtJwC0 3/3

name: European Central Bank
tweet: A digital euro would complement cash, not replace it. It would respect privacy, be available free of charge and facilitate secure digital payments in all corners of the euro area, backed by the commitment of an independent central bank to ensure its stability 2/3

name: European Central Bank
tweet: (THREAD) At the ECB we are committed to understanding people’s needs and ensuring the digital euro would be widely accepted, writes Executive Board member Fabio Panetta with Ulrich Bindseil in The ECB Blog  https://t.co/UMqavtJwC0 1/3  https://t.co/8nhLwFrWjA

name: European Central Bank
tweet: The new 2021 Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices weights show major shifts, with recreation and transport decreasing the most and food items and housing increasing the most. These drove headline and core inflation upwards in January  https://t.co/pwGTqLKTku #EconomicBulletin  https://t.co/NT4nz1KByU

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Industry, as well as countries such as Germany, also saw major effects during the start of the pandemic. They largely recovered during the second half of 2020, however, as economic agents learned to cope with containment measures  https://t.co/WXKfWp4dyD #EconomicBulletin 2/2

name: European Central Bank
tweet: How have containment measures hit different sectors and countries? Recreational services and countries such as Spain have been hit more heavily, and the effects of these measures are expected to continue in the short term. #EconomicBulletin 1/2  https://t.co/9pbTKvoqlO

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Excess liquidity in the euro area rose further due to purchase programmes and recent targeted measures (TLTROs). Government deposits fell from record levels, and will continue to be affected by pandemic-related uncertainties.  Read more  https://t.co/rS7vH44fu7 #EconomicBulletin

name: European Central Bank
tweet: The euro area saw stricter lockdowns, lower inflation and a bigger drop in economic activity than the US last year, where fiscal policy support was stronger overall but less supportive to jobs. Read more  https://t.co/Dz4zu5obBK #EconomicBulletin

name: European Central Bank
tweet: How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in February? How do they compare with January’s figures? Find out more in the press release  https://t.co/3edV452bKm  https://t.co/BdeRJ81uAz

name: European Central Bank
tweet: The latest Economic Bulletin is out! The Bulletin presents the economic and monetary information which forms the basis for our policy decisions. Read more  https://t.co/wFXTLIMZBo  https://t.co/CHUL40k4vn

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Congrats to our ECB colleagues who co-authored the working paper winning the award! Here's the link  https://t.co/gVRqyltzzH

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Our Chief Economist Philip R. Lane recently spoke with students from University College Dublin’s Economics Society.  He reflected on the current pandemic and offered advice for those interested in a career in economics.  Watch the interview  https://t.co/2hgoPT0hGD  https://t.co/qO4VBiqOYq

name: European Central Bank
tweet: While corporate sector profits fell during the crisis, profit margins have been particularly resilient relative to the depth of the recession. Job retention schemes likely played an important role in making this so. Read more  https://t.co/JUNvIKNT5b #EconomicBulletin

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Economic inequality has risen in recent decades, primarily due to globalisation and technological developments. Monetary policy has played only a minor role, and in fact has dampened it by encouraging job creation. Read more  https://t.co/1juHUnbfkj #EconomicBulletin  https://t.co/5m5JT8OlLv

name: European Central Bank
tweet: How does the coronavirus pandemic affect our economy? And what is the outlook for the coming months? Director General Economics Frank Smets discussed these topics with civil society representatives last week. Watch the full event here  https://t.co/705IqMRlME.

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Lane: As the recent US stimulus gets rolled out, it will be a significant engine for the world economy.  It will boost global GDP and boost exports from the euro area.  Read the transcript of the interview  https://t.co/2eDsqXfHQ6 3/3

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Lane: Our latest projections allow for some extension of lockdowns into the second quarter. The real concern is the underlying battle with the virus.  The risk of lockdowns will remain until the virus is more contained and until we have progress on vaccinations 2/3

name: European Central Bank
tweet: (THREAD) We are committed to a substantial increase in the pace of purchasing, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @CNBC in an interview.  He adds that weekly data on our purchases should not be examined in isolation but rather averaged over several weeks 1/3  https://t.co/bwKbH7wuoY

name: European Central Bank
tweet: The EU recovery package can contribute to a faster, stronger and more uniform recovery of our economy. This requires a balance of mutually reinforcing investments and reforms, increasing administrative capacity and reducing bottlenecks  https://t.co/4DFK8OlDnY #EconomicBulletin

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Why do consumers sometimes overestimate inflation? This is down to their uncertainty: those who aren’t certain tend to round up, and their expectations tend to be higher than actual inflation. This is made worse during crisis periods.  https://t.co/6XjJrwNh7t #EconomicBulletin  https://t.co/GSw504xvsr

name: European Central Bank
tweet: As a direct result of the pandemic, banks’ return on equity fell from 5.2% at the end of 2019 to 2.1% in 2020. The crisis further highlighted weaknesses in banks’ asset quality, profitability, cost efficiency and the sustainability of their business models.  https://t.co/i3NJw15HU2

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Banks strengthened their capital levels in 2020: their Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio increased slightly from 2019 and stood at 15.2% in the third quarter of 2020. This was partly due to the extraordinary relief measures taken in response to the crisis.  https://t.co/j2krnB1zH4

name: European Central Bank
tweet: Our supervisory focus shifted rapidly in 2020: we offered temporary capital and operational relief to banks so that they could continue lending to households and firms. Read more in the ECB Annual Report 2020 on supervisory activities  https://t.co/R90MJkZtOs  https://t.co/OBBCIapW5b
